newsitem.title: FINLAND: FINNISH EXCHANGE MERGER SEEN CUTTING COSTS.
newsitem.headline: FINNISH EXCHANGE MERGER SEEN CUTTING COSTS.

text.p: A planned merger of the Helsinki bourse and derivatives exchange SOM may cut costs and boost derivatives trading, but it was no surprise, analysts said.
By joining forces, the two exchanges can reach synergy benefits in technology and other cost savings, and the link-up was a logical event locally, they said on Tuesday.
"This was a positive thing locally," said Patrick Hertzberg, head of equities in Helsinki at Swedish Handelsbanken.
"If you develop a system, I should imagine it can easily make use of it for many products, so yes, I see clear synergy benefits," he said.
FIM Securities managing director Jaakko Ylitalo agreed, and added: "We also might see more brokers trading on the derivatives side."

Swedish derivatives exchange OM Gruppen -- which will have a 16 percent stake in the new exchange if all owners convert their holdings -- said the merger was very positive, with scope to boost liquidity.
"Their (the exchanges') challenge is to create liquidity and client value and we think this solution gives chances for this," it said.
Banking group Merita will be the biggest owner in the new exchange -- to be called HEX Oy -- with a 30 percent stake, but voting power will capped at 1/20 of the total.

The exchanges said the merger would create a stronger and more versatile exchange and promote international cooperation based on networking; but some experts still called for more cooperation across borders in the Nordic countries.
"Instead of defending national positions, they could instead be looking to cooperate more with other exchanges," said one who spoke on condition of anonymity.
"At this time we are not engaged in any negotiations in any direction," SOM chairman Juha Korhonen told a news conference.
"The future is the future, and we believe that with what we have now we will be a strong partner," he said when asked about possible plans for international bourse cooperation.

One expert said SOM and its owners had traditionally been more open and flexible than the bourse. This may help international projects since the SOM's owners acquired a larger share -- 60 percent -- of the new exchange, he added.
